body: Yuri Grigorovich's version of "The Nutcracker" for his new troupe, the Bolshoi Ballet Grigorovich Company, promised three leading casts, and Saturday's matinee introduced an exceptional and elegant young dancer named Aleksei Musatov as the Nutcracker Prince to partner Tatyana Kutina, who made her debut in the ballerina role. But on Friday night,
title: Review/Dance; New 'Nutcracker' Prince

body: The owner of a Brooklyn restaurant was shot to death yesterday afternoon by police officers when he refused to drop a sawed-off shotgun that he had pointed at the officers in his restaurant, the police said. The dead man was tentatively identified as Juan Cruz, of 408 South Second Street in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn. A police spokesman,
title: Armed Restaurateur Shot to Death by Police

body: "It's a gorgeous space, isn't it?" said Mbongeni Ngema, surveying the magnificent ruin of the Majestic Theater in Brooklyn, with its purposefully renovated interiors of bare brick, raw plaster and the decaying remnants of its golden age. Onstage, in what seemed an extension of the space, was a battered shantytown, a stage set of corrugated shacks,
title: South African Harmonies on a Brooklyn Stage

body: A six-inch pipe bomb ready for detonation was found early yesterday on a ramp used by delivery trucks at The Daily News's Brooklyn printing plant, the police said. In other incidents yesterday, the police arrested two replacement drivers on weapons charges and a striking pressman who was charged with assaulting a vendor. A police unit assigned to
title: Police at News's Plant Find An Unexploded Pipe Bomb

body: Rhys Chatham, who will be performing a new score called "The Heart Cries With Many Voices," for a blend of rock instruments, brass and early-music singers tonight and tomorrow night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is only 38 years old. One says "only" because that would still count as young for most classical composers, which is what Mr. Chatham
title: Composer Firmly on the Side of All Genres

body: The image of the long-distance runner, alone while watched by a crowd, has been turned, especially by films, into a metaphor for social conflict. Yet this is the same idea the choreographer Susan Marshall employs, with eight dancers in athletic gear constantly returning to a starting line, sprinting ahead or falling. That she makes a race and the
title: Review/Dance; At Next Wave Series, Moving and Moving Hard

body: Officer Richard Stasio rapped sharply on the side door of 934 Cranford Avenue, a two-family home in the Wakefield section of the Bronx. "Good morning, I'm with the Sanitation Police. Are you the owner?" he asked, wearing a crisp blue uniform and cap. "Yes," said Anthony M. Benns, wearing a confused look and not much else. "Excuse me," said Officer
title: For 'Recycling Cops,' Dragnets Turn Up Bottles and Cans

body: Brushing aside the New York City Police Department's objections, a Federal judge ruled yesterday that the police must allow striking Daily News workers to expand their picket lines at the newspaper's main printing plant in Brooklyn. The judge, Jack B. Weinstein, also ordered The News not to evade the pickets by having its nonunion workers enter and
title: Judge Approves New Picket Site At News Plant

body: The Daily News opened a new front against its striking unions yesterday, announcing that it was filing civil suits against 11 people whose actions, it said, had hurt sales of the newspaper and damaged the company's ability to do business. The complaints, to be filed in the civil division of New York State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, grew out of
title: News Sues 11 in Strike, Citing Acts of Violence

body: Charitable organizations that maintained more than one account in the failed Freedom National Bank stand to lose hundreds of thousands of dollars that they had thought was protected by Federal deposit insurance. Officials of the community services organizations, which provide day care, programs for the elderly, foster care, housing and assistance
title: Charities Face Large Losses In Failed Bank

body: Ginette Laurin, perhaps the most interesting of Montreal's experimental choreographers, creates movement and images that are original and startling -- yes, something different from what others do. In "Chagall," the artist's lovers come alive as Miss Laurin's dancers loom over a miniature village, then fling themselves headlong through space. In
title: Review/Dance; Keeping Images in Focus Amid the Hurtling Bodies

body: Anyone who has mistakenly wandered onto a nudist beach will feel right at home in the audience at the Brooklyn Academy of Music when nearly 70 naked performers, diverse in size, race and age, end a sprawling three-hour discourse on freedom by the choreographer Bill T. Jones. "Last Supper at Uncle Tom's Cabin/The Promised Land" is anything but a
title: Review/Dance; Bill T. Jones In a Quest For Truth

body: Christopher Gillis and Margie Gillis, brother and sister, are magnificent dancers, and although they are rarely together on the stage, they have joined forces this week for the kind of concert you will never see anywhere else. Both are exceptional performers, very popular in New York, and on Tuesday night they opened the third entry in the series
title: Review/Dance; Siblings Who Stress Individuality

body: A 38-year-old French artist unveiled his latest painting in SoHo last week and promptly faced the critics. Le Pointre, as he calls himself, was at the top of a wobbly 20-foot ladder, trying to glue and nail his 11-foot-wide canvas to a brick wall, when they started questioning the motivation behind this work. "Do you have the permission of the
title: A Wall in SoHo; Enter 2 Artists, Feuding

body: Wanda Panfil, the woman an ailing Grete Waitz said she had to beat to win the New York City Marathon for an unprecedented 10th time, proved the nine-time champion an accurate prophet of her own doom yesterday by doing just what Waitz had fearfully predicted: She started out strong in Staten Island, pulled away from the pack in Brooklyn and never
title: NEW YORK CITY MARATHON; Panfil Starts Fast, Holds Off Challenge

body: Maybe it was Samuel Robinson, a 37-year-old homeless man, who best summed up the spectator appeal of yesterday's marathon. He watched it in Harlem, in front of the Handmaids of Mary Convent at 15 West 124th Street, standing in a soup-kitchen line with dozens of people clapping and screaming at the runners, "Pump it up, man!" and "You can do it!"
title: NEW YORK CITY MARATHON; Support On Street Is Very Generous

body: The publisher of The Daily News, James Hoge, said yesterday that harassment of news vendors by striking union members had cut so deeply into his paper's circulation that the company had begun giving away 200,000 copies a day. The publisher called the giveaway program a direct response to the paper's circulation problems in the midst of the walkout
title: CIRCULATION HURT, NEWS GIVES AWAY MANY OF ITS COPIES

body: At least 13,000 municipal workers and others joined an angry rally outside The Daily News yesterday to show support for the paper's nine striking unions. While the police said there were no arrests or injuries at the paper's midtown office tower, several scuffles erupted during the demonstration, which capped a day of rising emotions in a labor
title: Municipal Employees Join Demonstration at The News

body: "Le Dortoir" ("The Dormitory") is not a masterpiece, but within the genre of dance-theater it is extremely well done. As six men and six women spend considerable time levitating above rows of brass beds that symbolize a regimented adolescence in a French Canadian boarding school, Gilles Maheu's company, Carbone 14, evokes a familiar era from a
title: Review/Dance; Reflections From Quebec on Adolescence and the 60's

body: It began on the graveyard shift with a worker's petty dispute in a battered old newspaper plant in Brooklyn, a place where huge printing presses rumble in the night and bundles of inky paperC move on conveyor belts under bare bulbs to wire-balers and waiting delivery trucks. In the predawn dark last Thursday, as scores of drivers, mailers, pressmen
title: The News Strike: From Job Dispute to Maelstrom

body: The Daily News began to transform its newsroom yesterday, bringing in the first wave of out-of-state replacement editors and reporters to help its hard-pressed in-house staff of management supervisors. The dozen or so newsroom substitutes, recruited for temporary duty from papers in Florida and Illinois, were said to have been put to work shortly
title: Nonunion Newsroom Staff Is Expanded for The News

body: The Daily News, struck by nine of its 10 unions, began dismissing most of its 2,400 unionized workers yesterday and then struggled to publish without them, gathering an army of nonunion employees, some from across the country, to write, edit, print and deliver the nation's second-largest metropolitan daily. With scores of replacement drivers,
title: DAILY NEWS DROPS UNION EMPLOYEES

body: The 700-member newspaper deliverers' union local struck The Daily News last night, setting off a climactic labor showdown with the management of the financially ailing paper, the nation's second largest metropolitan daily. Within minutes, eight other unions representing most of the paper's 2,400 unionized workers announced that they would honor the
title: Drivers Strike at The Daily News, Ande Most Unions Honor Walkout

body: The central symbol in the image-laden "Ninagawa Macbeth" is a large cherry tree spreading its blossoms and shimmering in the light. As the play progresses and as Macbeth's plot fails, spring turns autumnal and the petals begin to fall. When Birnam Wood moves, branches of that tree are carried across the stage. As directed in Japanese by Yukio
title: Review/Theater; Universality of 'Macbeth' in Japanese

title: Review/Dance; Baryshnikov Takes A New Direction With Morris Troupe

body: LEAD: Production of new housing in New York City rode a strong economy to a 14-year high last year, but the good news for a housing-starved city will probably not last long. Developers say that with inventories of market-rate housing high and buyers scarce, the city's private home-building sector will soon be as quiet as a vacant apartment.
title: New Housing Outlook For New York Is Gloomy

title: WHAT REALLY MAKES NEW YORK WORK; THE PEOPLE WHO GREASE THE WHEELS
